name: Chapter 5: Elastic Load Balancer
description: Flashcards explaining Elastic Load Balancing and its integration with Auto Scaling using pizza shop metaphors.

cards.front: Your application is deployed across several EC2 instances. How do you ensure incoming traffic is distributed evenly to avoid overloading one instance?
cards.back: Use Elastic Load Balancing (ELB) to automatically distribute incoming application traffic across multiple Amazon EC2 instances, improving availability and responsiveness.
cards.example: An online food ordering system uses ELB to balance requests between multiple EC2 servers during high-traffic periods.
cards.mnemonic: Let the host seat the guestsâ€”not the oven.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: AWS service that automatically distributes traffic across multiple EC2 instances or other targets.
Scalable virtual server environment for running applications in the AWS cloud.

cards.front: How does the load balancer respond when EC2 Auto Scaling adds or removes instances during traffic changes?
cards.back: Elastic Load Balancing dynamically adjusts and includes or excludes EC2 instances as they are added or removed by Auto Scaling, ensuring traffic is always routed efficiently.
cards.example: A mobile app that experiences spikes during lunch hours sees EC2 Auto Scaling add instances, and ELB instantly routes traffic to the new instances.
cards.mnemonic: New ovens? No problem. The host knows.
cards.subject: Cloud Support Basics
cards.course: Skills and Best Practices for Cloud Support Associates

glossary.definition: Automatically adjusts EC2 instance count based on demand.
Distributes incoming traffic to multiple backend resources for better availability.

cards.front: During periods of low and high demand, how does ELB maintain application performance?
cards.back: ELB works with Auto Scaling to distribute traffic evenly across available EC2 instances, regardless of the number running, maintaining performance and preventing overload.
cards.example: A retail site uses ELB to maintain fast page loads by routing user requests to underutilized EC2 instances during flash sales.
cards.mnemonic: Few customers? Few registers. Big crowd? Big spread.

glossary.definition: A service that distributes application traffic to multiple resources to improve availability and reliability.
Automatically adds or removes EC2 instances based on application demand.
